title: Melissa Etheridge: Trump bigger threat to gay rights than Pence
text:
Melissa Etheridge performs at the 14th annual Woman's Day Red Dress Awards at the Lincoln Center. (Rabbani & Solimene Photography) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Wednesday, February 8, 2017, 6:30 PM 
Singer Melissa Etheridge says that she attended a same-sex wedding two years ago and Donald Trump was there. Looking back now, she wonders how the man who’s now spearheading a radical conservative movement made the cut. 
“I always think the best of people so no, I never thought we would be on this side of that ,” Etheridge said at the 14th annual Woman’s Day Red Dress Awards at Lincoln Center on Tuesday. 
Whether the gay couple who got married regrets inviting Trump, Etheridge doesn't know. She also seems confused about how The Donald got tied up with people like Vice President Mike Pence, who as the governor of Indiana, frequently championed anti-gay legislation. 
“I can't speak (for the couple), but this is New York City and I'm sure there's a lot of people who worked with (Trump) and socialized with him who are rolling their eyes and going, ‘Really?’” she said. 
Though Pence has been outspoken about his anti-gay sentiments for years, the Grammy- and Oscar-winning singer says that as a gay woman, Trump worries her more “because there's an uneducated, unregulated part of him.” Singer-songwriter Melissa Etheridge isn't the only one wondering how President Trump will deal with LGBT issues. (ANGELA WEISS/AFP/Getty Images) 
(Despite the president’s world view , it's worth noting that he is a University of Pennsylvania grad.) 
Etheridge says that the president’s cavalier approach to governing is less reasonable than Pence and his peers' respect for the democratic process. 
“At least Mike Pence, even if he’s against my lifestyle and he's very conservative, he at least had a certain... to the social conservatives there was at least a sense of... following the rules,” she said. 
After speaking with us, Etheridge went on to perform hit songs “Come to My Window,” “I Wanna Be In Love,” “I Run For Life,” and “I'm the Only One” for Red Dress supporters including former NBC correspondent Tamron Hall, ex E! reporter Alicia Quarles, retired boxer Laila Ali, singer Lena Hall and comedian Jane Lynch, who hosted the event that raised money to fight heart disease in women.
